title: Understanding Spontaneity
text: A reaction is spontaneous when the Gibbs free energy change, ΔG, is less than zero. Use the equation $$ΔG=ΔH-TΔS$$ to determine the temperature at which ΔG becomes zero.

title: Rearranging the Equation
text: To find the temperature at which the reaction becomes spontaneous, rearrange the equation $$ΔG=ΔH-TΔS$$ to solve for T when ΔG is zero.

title: Setting ΔG to Zero
text: Set ΔG to zero in the equation $$ΔG=ΔH-TΔS$$. This will help you find the temperature at which the reaction becomes spontaneous.

title: Solving for Temperature
text: After setting ΔG to zero, solve the equation $$0=ΔH-TΔS$$ for T. This will give you the temperature at which the reaction becomes spontaneous.

title: Units Consistency
text: Ensure that the units for ΔH and ΔS are consistent when solving for T. Convert ΔH from $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$ to $$\frac{J}{mol}$$ if necessary.
